item.title: Introducing EverNode – Scott Chamberlain

item.description:
Because the XRP Ledger is an open and decentralized network, no one individual or entity can unilaterally make a change that would impact how it operates. So how does a change get made?
There’s an established governance process that’s enforced by all the participants and nodes on the Ledger. These rules are important to understand both for general knowledge about how the Ledger functions, and for those who might want to add new functionality that the Ledger doesn’t currently have.
Network changes go through what’s called an amendment process. This means that desired changes are proposed to the network for review, and then the validator nodes vote on whether or not to accept them. 80% of the validators need to agree to the proposed changes. With amendments, the approval level needs to remain above 80% for two weeks. During that time, validators are free to change their vote. But once this 80% agreement is achieved for two weeks, the amendment is ratified and ready to go live.
Learn more: xrpl.org
item.title: Governance and the Amendment Process
Apex: XRPL Dev Summit 2022 - Exploring AMMs and Introduction to Zeuswap, Bruce Silvera II

item.description:
On the XRP Ledger, there’s a peer-to-peer network of independent nodes that processes transactions and maintains the shared state of the ledger. If you want to submit transactions, read ledger data, or otherwise participate in the network, then your application will connect to a NODE on this network.
Nodes can be run by anyone - individuals, universities, corporations, exchanges, wallet-providers.
In this video, you'll learn about the different types of nodes and how they work.
Learn more: xrpl.org
item.title: Nodes and Validators

item.description:

The first call was moderated by Daniel, CTO of Casino Coin, and Yolk, Founder of Clever Gallery, with contributions from Nik Bougalis, Head of Engineering at RippleX, Wietse Wind, Founder at XRPL Labs and XummWallet, and Scott Determan, Principal Software Engineer at RippleX.

Apex: XRPL Dev Summit 2022 - Empowering Everyday Businesses with DeFi, Sean Bennett

item.description:
The XRP Ledger was the first blockchain to support the tokenization of a variety of assets.
This includes stablecoins or other forms of value – anything from US dollars, to euros, gold, stocks, and other cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin or Ethereum – and even non-fungible tokens (NFTs) that might represent valuable items like pieces of art or cinema tickets.
Tokens are often called issued assets, or IOUs, on the XRPL.
Learn more: xrpl.org
item.title: Tokenization

item.description:
Stefan Thomas, CEO of Coil and former CTO of Ripple, and David Schwartz, CTO of Ripple, sit down for a fireside chat to discuss the rapidly changing world of crypto, the future of Coil, Thomas' time at Ripple and more.
Learn more: apexdevsummit.com
item.title: An Open Future – Coil CEO Stefan Thomas and Ripple CTO David Schwartz
Apex: XRPL Dev Summit 2022 - Aesthetes: Bridging Fine Art and Blockchain, Luca Bertolani

item.title: Boto Corp Overview – Breno Araujo

item.title: Ripple's CBDC Ledger – David Fueling

Aanchal Malhotra, Senior Software Engineer of Cryptography at Ripple, and Greg Weisbrod, Senior Software Engineer at Ripple, discuss the XLS-20 standard for Non-Fungible Tokens on the XRP Ledger.

item.title: Non-Fungible Tokens on XRP Ledger – Aanchal Malhotra & Gregory Weisbrod
Apex: XRPL Dev Summit 2022 - How to Design Tokenomics for Your Project

item.description:
Elliot Lee, Staff Software Engineer at RippleX, introduces the XRPL Grants Program. XRPL Grants fund open-source projects that continue to advance the growing XRP Ledger community.
It funds both core technology and end-user applications including, but not limited to Sidechains, Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs), Core infrastructure, Developer tooling, Developer UX and Security.
Learn more: XRPLgrants.org and apexdevsummit.com
item.title: Introduction to XRPL Grants – Elliot Lee
Apex: XRPL Dev Summit 2022 - How to Design a Custom Sidechain, Mayukha Vadari

item.description:
The XRP Ledger was the first blockchain to feature a decentralized exchange – or DEX – which allows anyone to directly buy, sell and trade assets of all kinds without have to go through an intermediary, like a bank. And it's built to enable a highly efficient exchange of currencies, or of more unique forms of value.
Learn how the DEX works, and why transactions can be completed within three or four seconds at an extremely low cost.
Learn more: xrpl.org
item.title: Decentralized Exchange (DEX)

item.description:
Reto Steimen, Developer at Radynamics, shares how Radynamics has integrated the XRPL into existing accounting systems through cryptocurrency payments.
Learn more: apexdevsummit.com
item.title: Integrating XRPL into Accounting Systems – Reto Steimen

item.description:
Blockchain technology was developed with a bold ambition – to create more inclusive and equitable financial systems. And one appeal of a blockchain is that there’s no single, central arbiter that makes the rules, maintains the ledger, and confirms transactions.
As energy-intensive currencies and technologies grow in popularity, unfortunately their negative environmental impact scales as well. Some blockchains already consume as much energy in a year as entire countries.
The XRP Ledger is different, and that’s entirely by design. In addition to all the utility it provides developers – speed, efficiency, low costs – it’s also a natively green ledger. That’s been an objective right from the start.
Learn more: xrpl.org
item.title: Sustainability of the XRP Ledger

item.description:
Mayukha Vadari, Software Engineer at RippleX, shares an overview of xrpl-py, the library for interacting with the XRP Ledger. The library closely mirrors rippled in its interfaces, meaning that you can use both library specific documentation as well as all other documentation.
Learn more: apexdevsummit.com
item.title: Programming with xrpl-py – Mayukha Vadari

item.title: How Forte is Unlocking Token Economics, Starting with Gaming – Christopher Jimison

item.description:
The XRP Ledger makes it easy to support transactions across multiple currencies and forms of value. Payments can be made directly in the Ledger’s native asset XRP, or with any asset tokenized on the XRP Ledger – US dollars, euros, Bitcoin, gold, or stocks, for example.
Learn more: xrpl.org
item.title: Advanced Payment Features of the XRPL
Apex: XRPL Dev Summit 2022 - The State of the XRP Ledger Foundation, Thomas Silkjaer & Scott Branson

item.description:
To make a transaction on the ledger – which means to send, receive, or place an offer to exchange money or other forms of value - an ACCOUNT is needed. These are also sometimes called wallets.
In this video, you'll learn about the components and features of accounts, as well as how to set up an account.
Learn more: xrpl.org
item.title: Accounts

item.description:
XLS-20 is a new standard for NFTs on the XRP Ledger. An NFT, or Non-Fungible Token, is a unique, one-of-a-kind, digital asset often linked to the ownership of something of value—such as a piece of art, movie ticket, carbon credit, or even a home title.
Typically, NFTs are created and managed using smart contracts that can result in slower operations and increased costs. To do away with the need for smart contracts and improve the user experience when minting or managing NFTs, XLS-20 introduces support for native NFT objects so any account on the XRPL can mint, own and trade a non-fungible token.
Just like other transactions on the XRP Ledger, NFT operations are fast and cheap. Offers to buy and sell an NFT can be made in any asset available on the XRP Ledger without the need for an external trading platform. NFT support on the XRP Ledger also opens up exciting opportunities for developers and offers new functionality to build new use cases.
Learn more about the fundamentals of the XRP Ledger at XRPL.org.
item.title: NFTs on the XRP Ledger
Apex: XRPL Dev Summit 2022 - European Crypto Regulation: Going Global? Peter Merc

item.description:

item.title: Xplorer.com Impacting Criminal Finances – Thomas Silkjaer

item.description:
With a decentralized ledger, there’s no single, central arbiter that confirms transactions. But there does need to be a method to ensure that all network participants execute transactions correctly and consistently.
In this video, we'll review the different ways to reach this agreement, and how the XRPL confirms transactions via the consensus algorithm.
Learn more: xrpl.org
item.title: The Consensus Mechanism
Apex: XRPL Dev Summit 2022 - Blockchain: Law as an Enabler and a Stumbling Block, N.S. Nappinai

item.description:
Ryan Molley, Founder of WhirleldLabs, showcases unique new ways to connect merchants with customers via peer-to-peer communication on the XRP Ledger, enabling easier payment flow for users.

item.title: The Internet of Things Meets the Internet of Value – Ryan Molley

item.description:
Bharath Chari, Board Member of the XRP Ledger Foundation, discusses the work that XRPL developers are doing on the ledger and provides a brief overview of what's in the XRPL Foundation's pipeline.

item.title: The XRPL Foundation – Bharath Chari
Apex: XRPL Dev Summit 2022 - Ziggurat: Ensuring Peer-to-Peer Network Stability, Mark Henderson

item.description:
The second XRP Ledger Developer Community Call took place on August 3, 2022 to discuss updates about the second Apex Developer Summit, as well as the XRPL amendment voting process.
The call was moderated by Daniel Keller from the XRPL Community Ambassador program, with special guests an independent UNL validator, and Nik Bougalis, Head of RippleX Engineering.
item.title: XRP Ledger Developer Community Call #2

item.description:
What is the XRP Ledger? In this video series, learn about the key concepts of the XRP Ledger – a decentralized, permissionless, open-source blockchain that anybody can contribute to, develop on, and transact on.
The XRP Ledger has operated continuously since January 2013, and over 1.8 billion transactions have been completed as of 2021.
Learn more: xrpl.org
item.title: Intro to the XRP Ledger

item.description:
Briana Marbury, Executive Director of The Interledger Foundation, discusses the Foundation's mission to expand the public's understanding of the Interledger protocol, an inter-payment standard which has an immense potential to advance the financial inclusion for roughly 1/4 of the world's underbanked and unbanked population.
Learn more: apexdevsummit.com
item.title: The Interledger Foundation – Briana Marbury

item.description:
Mo Morsi, Founder and CEO of Dev Null Productions, discusses the history of blockchains, and the XRP Ledger specifically, and dives into the code that runs the XRPL.

item.title: Through the Looking Glass: How the XRPL Works – Mo Morsi
